message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone indicates congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and among the options, only a deficiency of 21-hydroxylase can cause this. The ambiguous genitalia also supports this diagnosis. Serum sodium is low and serum potassium is high, which are common findings in congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) with deficient steroidogenesis, and the laboratory results show elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels, which is consistent with CAH due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The ambiguous genitalia is also a common feature in CAH. Deficiency of 11-beta-hydroxylase can also cause hypertension, but the laboratory results do not match. Deficiency of 17-alpha-hydroxylase will cause hypertension and decreased sex hormones secretion, but the laboratory results suggest increased androgen levels. Deficiency of placental aromatase will not cause CAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH), and among the options, only a deficiency of 21-hydroxylase can cause CAH with symptoms of excessive vomiting and poor feeding. The elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone level confirms the diagnosis of CAH due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The ambiguity of genitalia also supports this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high level of 17-hydroxyprogesterone suggests a congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and the ambiguous genitalia indicates a deficiency in hormone production. Among the options, only deficiency of 21-hydroxylase can cause the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia caused by deficiency of 21-hydroxylase. This deficiency leads to a decrease in cortisol and aldosterone levels, as well as an increase in androgen levels, which could explain the ambiguous genitalia. The elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels also indicate this deficiency. Deficiency of 11-beta-hydroxylase and 17-alpha-hydroxylase can also cause congenital adrenal hyperplasia, but they present with different hormone imbalances. Deficiency of placental aromatase would not cause these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This can cause excessive vomiting and poor feeding, dehydration and shock, and ambiguous genitalia. Elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone are also a hallmark of this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant has ambiguous genitalia and a serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone level 10-100 times higher than normal. These are classic signs of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH). Deficiency of 21-hydroxylase is the most common form of CAH, which leads to excess androgen production causing ambiguous genitalia in females. The elevated serum potassium levels in 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency and hypertension and feminization in 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency could not explain the clinical picture. Deficiency of placental aromatase will affect the production of estrogen in females, but it is not related to CAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high level of 17-hydroxyprogesterone suggests an adrenal insufficiency, and the ambiguous genitalia suggests a congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Among the options, only deficiency of 21-hydroxylase leads to CAH. The low serum sodium and high serum potassium also support the diagnosis of CAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant presents with ambiguous genitalia, which suggests a congenital adrenal hyperplasia. The elevated serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone level is a key diagnostic finding in 21-hydroxylase deficiency, the most common type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which is associated with excessive androgen production. The low serum sodium level and high serum potassium level are consistent with adrenal insufficiency, which is a feature of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency and 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency can also result in ambiguous genitalia, but they typically present with hypertension, not shock. Placental aromatase deficiency is extremely rare and typically presents in utero with maternal virilization and masculinization of female fetuses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ambiguous genitalia, enlarged clitoris, and elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Among the options, only deficiency of 21-hydroxylase can cause CAH. The low serum sodium level and high serum potassium level are also consistent with this diagnosis.
